newsitem.title: UK: Sleaze dogs government, Labour holds big poll lead.
newsitem.headline: Sleaze dogs government, Labour holds big poll lead.

text.p: With a "sleaze" scandal dogging Britain's ruling Conservatives, local party members meet on Tuesday to decide whether former minister Neil Hamilton should stand as a candidate in the May 1 general election.

The election campaign was enlivened on Monday when one of Britain's best-known journalists, BBC war reporter Martin Bell, said he would stand as an "anti-corruption" candidate against Hamilton, who denies allegations that he took cash to ask questions in parliament for business interests.
The Conservative majority of some 22,000 in Hamilton's Tatton constituency in northwest England looks under threat if he is the party's candidate.
"I'm not confident that Martin Bell will pull this off, but I think he deserves to, I'd love to see him do it," said one Tatton man interviewed by BBC radio.

"I think Hamilton should stand down. Whether he's innocent or guilty, I don't think that makes any difference now, I think it's gone too far and he should stand down," a female constituent told the news programme.

The Conservatives have been hit by a series of financial and sex scandals, undermining confidence in the government of John Major even though Britain's economic situation is relatively good, with unemployment falling and inflation low.
A poll published in Tuesday's Daily Telegraph newspaper puts Labour 20 points ahead of the Conservatives with the backing of 53 percent of the electorate.
"The swing towards Labour since the 1992 election now stands at 13.8 percent and the projected Labour majority (in the lower House of Commons) is 211," the Telegraph said.
Secure in that 20-point lead, Labour leader Tony Blair admitted on Monday that his party had been slow to modernise itself in the 1980s when it stuck to socialist policies like nationalisation.
"There were certain things the Conservatives got right in the 1980s and we should have been quicker to face up to that," he said in an interview on BBC television.
Blair said that Labour may have changed its policies but its principles remained the same.

"We always believed in the idea of a more just and more fair society, and the Labour Party believed for a long period of time that the way to do that was, for example, greater nationalisation...was for example, simply more increased state spending.
"The whole process of modernisation has been to take the Labour Party away from that -- keep true to its principles but put those principles properly in a modern setting," he said.
Earlier on Tuesday, in a speech to a business audience in London, Blair stressed his party's new-found faith in market forces and its rejection of nationalisation and high taxes.

The party's economics spokesman, Gordon Brown, refused to rule out proceeding with Conservative plans to privatise Britain's air traffic control industry. Labour had previously opposed the sell-off on safety grounds.

Newspapers speculated that other assets, including the Royal Mail postal service, could also be sold off, a prospect greeted with anger by the postal workers' union, which led a successful fight to make the Conservatives shelve privatisation plans.
